title: Before 12 September 2019, how many candidates who participated at the second Democratic presidential primary debates on 30-31 July will cease to be candidates?
preds: Going all in on the last day for that sweet 0.0001 score boost.

Looks like only three towards end of period. Low poll candidates probably are looking for fallout of few candidates from debate and have secured enough money to hang hang on for little while and replace them.

I read that DeBlasio is saying that if he doesn't make the cut for the October debate, he'll consider dropping out then, otherwise, all of the candidates are saying they're in the race until at least Iowa.
Would be surprised to see anyone drop out this close to the next debate.

At this time, Hickenlooper, GIllibrand, Inslee are the only three who have withdrawn. Of the remaining candidates who were NOT invited to the next debate, only Ryan has been relatively media silent the last two weeks. With the short time remaining, I fully expect the total to stay below 5 over the next couple of days.

Steyer qualifies for the October debates, making total qualified at 11.
Gabbard currently out of Oct for October, depending on polling qualification criteria.  If 2% of responses is used, she is out. If 2% of qualified voters is used she is in. Current decision process for the debates continues to allow addition candidates to qualify.
Although 6 candidates have not yet met either the poll or the donor threshold.
https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/at-least-11-candidates-will-make-the-fourth-democratic-debate/
To Improve the capacity for forecasting

The following candidates have dropped out:
- Kirsten Gillibrand
- John Hickenlooper
- Jay Inslee Given the short time frame remaining and the activity / behavior of the remaining candidates I don't think any more will drop out before 12th September.
Data provided (by link above is predicted 12-13 won't get a pass to the next level.

This article describes what it's like to be one of the candidates running a campaign which hasn't garnered a lot of attention.  https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/04/us/politics/bullock-bennet-democrats-2020.html?utm_source=&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=24446 Campaigns & candidates have had time to assess their Labor Day performance and none have made any announcement.  Only 5 more days until this question closes.  Reducing my forecast for 2 or more additional withdrawals due to passage of time.

Due to passage of time, I am reducing all candidates who have explicitly vowed to stay on (research here [2]) to 1%. Gabbard is campaigning in NH until Saturday [1]. Hence, she is not acting like a candidate about to drop out. Reducing to 10% (from 30%). For de Blasio, based on a google search and his Facebook page, he doesn't seem to be doing a big campaigning push. He's also come under pressure lately from the media to get back to his duties as mayor. Latest polling has him at 0.5% [3] I am increasing him to 60% (from 30%). Williamson is still 5% Result: reducing last bucket from 14%. [1] https://www.nbcboston.com/news/local/Rep-Tulsi-Gabbard-Headlining-Politics-Eggs-Breakfast-NH-559445421.html
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/901273
[3] https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/latest_polls/democratic_nomination_polls/
It seems like possibly only one more candidate will drop out in the next week. But 2 could drop at the same time. I was expecting some more announcements after the holiday weekend.

de Blasio "said he would probably drop out of the race if he does not qualify for the Democratic presidential debate in October." [1] Verdict for the forecast: reducing last bucket from 16% but still noting that the fact de Blasio is mulling dropping out leaves the possibility of him dropping out in time for this question (e.g. what if he decided early that his chances of qualifying for the next debate are nil?) [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/04/nyregion/de-blasio-2020-president.html

Candidate - Chance of Dropping Out
Ryan - 3%
Gabbard - 10%
Williamson - 3%
de Blasio - 10% (lowering from 20% given article below that says he will drop if he doesn't make the October debate which has a deadline of Oct 1)
Bullock - 3%
Bennet - 3%
Delaney - 3% 4% chance of 2+ candidates dropping (last bucket). One week left.  https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2019/09/04/de-blasio-may-quit-presidential-race-if-he-doesnt-make-october-debate-1168257
I see only 9 or 10 to advance to the next round.
Gillebrand, Hickenlooper, and Inslee are all out. I still think other candidates with a future (like Ryan and Bullock) are going to drop out soon, I just don't know if it will be in the next week.
Three are gone. Seven more are not in the next debate. If there's a 50% chance of each of those 7 dropping out (which I think is a bit low), .94 is the P(at least two drop out).

Both Bennet and DiBlasio have non functional  websites.Ar least in my chrome browser that only link you up to the Act Blue launch page to contribute to them. Even if their websites are functioning,it is apparent that each have little to add .
Each should get back to their respective jobs asap.
However based on @Emil I flipped my forecast 
as who knows when these gentlemen will return to their posts.Labor Day is over.They are missing 
In action from their real jobs.

Fortunately there are sharp people here who will spot errors in your reasoning. Thanks to @ccorcoran223 I realized that Steyer doesn't count for this question. Instead, it is Tim Ryan who does and who I haven't included in my analysis [1,2] Ryan stated quite emphatically that he'd stay regardless of whether he qualified for the third debate [3]. He seems to believe that with other centrist candidates leaving (like Hickenlooper) it opens the filed up for others like himself. Given he has vowed to stay in I assign a 3% of dropping out in the next 10 days. Further @ccorcoran223 brings up an important point that Gabbard may conceivably qualify for the next debate. I am therefore lowering her chances of dropping out in the next 10 days from 50% to 30%. I am also raising de Blasio to 30%. All in all I assume the following chances of dropping out in the next 10 days: delaney = 0.03
bullock = 0.03
williamson = 0.05
ryan = 0.03
gabbard = 0.3
deblasio = 0.3
bennet = 0.03  New forecast for 2 or more to drop out: 16% [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/900465
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/900705
[3] https://www.msnbc.com/velshi-ruhle/watch/rep-tim-ryan-on-how-he-s-going-to-stay-in-the-2020-race-66186309684

Going off Emil's estimates but lowering Gabbard down to 10%, and removing Steyer because he didn't participate in second debate.
Probability of all staying in: 62%
Probability of 1+ dropping: 38%
Probability of 2+ dropping: 6% (which would put total at 5+, i.e. last bucket)

Building on to my analysis [1], I am updating the assumed probability for Bennet to 3% as he has publicly said he will stay past the 3rd debate. [2,3] de Blasio has also stated, though not as directly that he'd stay. [4] After stating it outright, in a later interview "He declined to answer that question when POLITICO asked during an interview last week, saying he does not engage in “hypotheticals.”" I keep him at 20%. Gabbard has been vociferously attacking the DNC over the debate qualification criteria. This gives her an excuse to drop out but it's hard to say as it could also be a sign that she is staying as well. I keep her at 50%. The new probability that 2 or more will drop out is now 18%. I am thus reducing the 5th bucket, from 41%. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/900465
[2] https://www.cpr.org/2019/08/28/bennet-remains-defiant-as-he-misses-the-deadline-to-make-september-debate-stage/
[3] https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2019/08/michael-bennet-platform/596974/
[4] https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/city-hall/story/2019/08/12/looking-past-daunting-debate-qualifications-de-blasio-signals-he-will-keep-campaigning-for-president-1139839

There are a lot of candidates who may yet drop out but I will try to Fermi-ize this, break it into the individual candidates, try to assign reasonable chances to each, and see what happens. Out of the 2nd debate lineup [1], 10 have qualified to the third debate [2]. I assume all have a 0% chance of dropping out now. Three have dropped out. That leaves 7 candidates left:
- Steyer
- Gabbard
- Williamson
- de Blasio
- Bullock
- Bennet
- Delaney Delaney [3] and Bullock [4] have vowed to stay in the race. I conservatively assume 3% chance of counting for this question. Williamson is getting the national attention that supposedly motivated her to run, so I assume the chances are very low, 5%. Steyer is largely self-funded which gives his campaigns plenty of oxygen even if he doesn't qualify for the debates and allows him to harbor hopes that they may break out eventually. Steyer came close to qualifying for the 3rd debate [4] and may qualify for the 4th. I would assign a 3% chance of dropping out. That leaves Gabbard, de Blasio and Bennet. More research is required on these three. @Chrisp provides some valuable insights here [5]. In particular, Chrisp argues that de Blasio needs the platform. Let's assume 20% for him. Both Gabbard and Bennet had relatively large amount of fundraising cash on hand at the beginning of July [6] (relative to other minor candidates, although this is not a great metric. Let's assume 50% for each of them. According to this analysis, there is 41% chance that two or more candidates will drop out. @Anneinak, you mentioned you've read some candidates have committed to staying tin the race longer? Have I covered them? Are there any others? [1] https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/2nd-2020-democratic-presidential-debates-work/story?id=64249877
[2] https://www.vox.com/2019/8/8/20758519/september-democratic-debate-qualification-polls-candidates-yang-gabbard
[3] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/08/15/john-delaney-certainly-plans-to-stay-in-2020-race-if-he-misses-fall-debates.html
[4] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/28/us/politics/2020-democratic-debates.html
[5] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/896009
[6] https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/07/16/us/politics/democratic-fundraising-2020.html
I hope I'm right!  Need to thin the herd on this one pretty badly.

@Censusguyz has pointed out that we're headed into Labor Day weekend.  Candidates are probably booked to the max for the weekend.  Candidates will be judging the size of their crowds, enthusiasm of their supporters and donors, and the cost of continuing/vs ability to fund-raise.  Fundraising is the bane of every candidate's existence:  looking towards a future of fundraising may be the nail in the coffin of some campaigns. However, there's only 3 candidates who "count" so far.  That means that if there's one more, the 3-4 bucket is still the answer.  There has to be two more who withdraw to push the answer into the top bucket. . . . which two might they be?  Several candidates have said that there's no way that they're going to withdraw before Iowa in February.  Many other candidates may be thinking the same, and that if money gets tight they'd just keep a low/inexpensive profile elsewhere until then rather than withdraw.
3 have already withdrawn, 7 remaining can still qualify for the 4th debate or I'd have put 5+ higher
3 have already dropped out. 7 remaining that didn't make 3rd debate. Likely to see at least 2 more of the 10 candidates that were cut leave the race
If you did not make the stage this round, you are done, you just haven't found out yet, but post holiday the announcements will start.

I'm adjusting slightly as Gillebrand is out now, taking us to 3 total who were in the 2nd round of debates. I think it's possible that at least 2 more will drop before 9/12, but I'm hedging slightly that we'll only see one more drop out.

ABC news just updated the candidate list - halving the group from 20 down to 10.... those that failed to make the qualifying levels for participation in this 3rd debate have been removed  https://www.cnbc.com/2019/08/29/third-2020-democratic-primary-debate-lineup-set-biden-sanders-warren-lead-pack.html

Happened: Hickenlooper, Inslee, Gillibrand Likely: Bennet, Bullock, de Blasio, Delaney, Ryan, Gabbard, Williamson 
Very unlikely: Booker, Buttigieg, Castro, Klobuchar, O'Rourke, Yang, Biden, Harris, Sanders, Warren

Gillebrand is gone with dignity.Bennet and DeBlasio are substantially certain to follow.
Ryan has ceased fund raising emails to me.
Too expensive.
Gillibrand just dropped out. Total of 3 so far. More will come.
As each member drops, his/her support will go to other top performers, solidifying them and pushing other low lower candidates to even worse places.
Three outs! Time to change up percentages.
Gillibrand just dropped out; she's #3 for the purpose of this question.

Gillibrand drops out [1], making it 3 so far: Hickenlooper, Inslee, and Gillibrand. Splitting my 40% previously left in the 1-2 bucket evenly across 3-4 and 5+, so 50% and 10% to 70% and 30%, respectively. Crowd: 4%, 19%, 59%, 18% [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/08/28/kirsten-gillibrand-has-dropped-out-of-the-2020-presidential-race.html

1 Tim Ryan 
2 Beto O’Rourke 
3 Steve Bullock 
4 Kirsten Gillibrand 
5 Bill de Blasio 
6 Michael Bennet  Ryan vows to stay in the race. https://www.foxnews.com/politics/purge-begins-in-2020-democratic-primaries-as-cash-dries-up-and-debate-rules-tighten. O'Rourke unlikely to drop out.

Two have already dropped out at this point. At least four others are struggling to raise money. I think 1 or 2 may drop out. https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/us/politics/2020-presidential-candidates.html
Adjusting for the heck of it.

If we are going to see movement, it will be today through Friday.  Qualifying for Sept Debate. 
Will bump my rate back up, if not.

Swapping 1-2 and 3-4 to 40% and 50%, respectively given further consideration. In my initial prediction [1], I suspected Ryan might drop out, and I still think he's the most likely to do so after the September debate deadline passes on Wednesday. I think it's possible (>40%) that de Blasio, Gillibrand, or Bennet also drop out, although unlikely to be all of them. For what it's worth, Gillibrand did seem to be receptive to VP [2], but we probably shouldn't read too much into those gotcha questions. Steyer and Gabbard will stick it out to try for the October debate(s), which is like the September debates but with more time to meet the polling criteria. Bullock and Sestak (even though he doesn't count for this question) haven't been in the race long enough. Williamson and Delaney are in it for the long haul. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/890438
[2] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/heres-whos-qualified-for-the-third-debate-and-whos-on-the-bubble/

I don't think we can go with past data to make this determination. The number of candidates and the stakes in this campaign are unprecedented. Some will stay in just to have their say and make a point (think Marianne Williamson). My observation is that most who are running already are politicians and politicians tend to be a little narcissistic, so they don't throw in the towel quickly. My guess is Tim Ryan will drop out - the online information on him suggests he no longer is focusing on the presidential campaign. One other could will drop out but it looks like many who don't qualify for the third debate may hang in there anyway.
Seems a little early to be quitting. I don’t really know enough about it.
I think there is a good chance that one may drop out, but not more than that.

they don't want to miss the chance to raise their profile, even though they know they won't stand a chance. The first two people quiting the race, will push the remaining candidates to hang on for a little longer.
As time goes by, the lines get better and better defined. In such a crowded field, I find it unlikely that all those currently spending DNC resources will be going ahead.

Fascinating for a Political Scientist. There is a accumulating cascade of events behind the scenes. Each qualification for the stage by another candidate opens a Vista of smaller downstream events. Each failure to qualify ripples upstream as managers consider the impact on the distribution of voters they're courting. Offers are being made and refused or taken on a continuing basis, unabated by holidays or deadlines. i don't see more than a Dozen walk out on the stage.
2 candidates of the 20 who participate in the second set of debates have dropped out.

Inslee, Hickenlooper and Moulton have dropped out in the past nine days:
https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/why-seth-moultons-campaign-failed/

Hickenlooper (Senate, Colorado) and Inslee (Gov., Washington) both moved on to run for other posts. 
Seems the best odds are for additional low ranking candidates moving on to run for alternative offices.

Since 2 of the candidates are already out (Hickenlooper and Inslee, as previously noted, Moulton doesn't count), I think its likely that there will be at least 1 or 2 more who will drop out. The deadline to qualify for the next debate is August 28th, so I'll probably revise then as other people drop out.
https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2019/08/2020-candidates-president-guide/582598/

Moulton's out, but his withdrawal doesn't count because he wasn't in the second debate.  (Thanks to @Emil for reminding me of this!)  However, his decision is more evidence of what kinds of conversations must be going on in campaigns right now.
Raising 3-4 bucket now that Inslee has dropped out.
Moulton is out. Like a rolling snowball more are likely to come and soon
Shifting 10pp evenly from 1-2 to 3-4 and 5+ with Inslee dropping out. Crowd: 4%, 29%, 49%, 18%

Revising due to passage of time, and analysis by @Chrisp. As for the primaries overall, this is three weeks old, so probably obsolete, but still interesting: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/08/02/us/politics/2020-democratic-fundraising.html

So, I've been slow to make a prediction, mulling this out.  I did think inslee was on the way out, as I've posted in my last few predictions.  I know that most people, with 2 out, will be shifting to 3-4.    But that feels pre-mature to me.  It is still very early in the primary season.   We are still what .. 6 months earlier than the republican debates last cycle?   Also, both Trump, Obama showed that TV is not the sine-qua-non it once was.    The requirements for the October debate are the same as for the September debate.   People that are hitting the donors numbers will have cash to continue.  So - my inclination is to go all in  on 1-2.  Ie, no more will drop out prior to the debate. 
The qualifying date is Wednesday- but Finding out the dates of the qualifying polls would solidify that for me, but so far, no joy.  On the chopping block for the most likely to drop:  Gillibrand and Ryan. 
Gillibrand has been absolutely embarassing.  What this campaign has exposed is the fact that being appointed to position, she has no debate skills, no campaigning skills.    On the larger, strategic front she is a clintonista, and a new-yorker.  In other words, she does very little to bring people outside the typical democrats over.   Does nothing for the ticket. 
As she won re-election in 2018, she has absolutely no pressure to drop out.   Gillibrand is short on the donors and 3 polls short of qualifying.  But no real pressure.  Daughter/grand daughter of the Albany Democrat machine. My gut feel is that Gillibrand is an opportunist, running for vice-president.    But to be considered for VP - she has to get more votes, more eye-balls.  She's in till she runs out of money... Tim Ryan - very different story.   Ran as an underdog - and won.   Of course, it did help that the incumbent was in jail.   District is solidly democrat.   Ohio is a swing state - and winning it would drive a dagger into Trump's re-election plans.   He opposed Nancy Pelosi for speaker - which can't make life in the House comfortable, Pelosi notoriously holding grudges.  Final comments:  Bennet:  Bennet will benefit from Hickenlooper voters, and as of today, I make him likely to make October after missing September.   Bennet also has superb staff with strong ties to the DCCC.  So.  92-8.  And all in on 1-2 next friday if no one else drop out.  
Confidence: 20% (highly variable, no actual data/insight into the campaigns.) Smart play:  30% 1-2; 70% 3-4 then shift down to 1-2 after qualifying date.

cnn.com multiple candidates will not qualify.
Embarrassing for Senator Gillibrand not to qualify.
De Blasio has a city to run.
Governors gone. Except for Bullock,he will not make debate and will run for Senate.
Inslee was extremely impressive, went out with dignity, and has a future.

Shifting toward 3-4 since now Inslee and Hickenlooper are both out. Since they both have political futures (3rd term as governor and senate candidate respectively), it makes sense for them to focus on their future instead of a race they won't win. Based on that, I suspect Tim Ryan and Steve Bullock may drop out soon too, Ryan to focus on a comfortable reelection that will let him run for senate in 2022 and Bullock to run for senate this cycle. Most other candidates at the bottom (ie Gillibrand or Bennet) don't face the same competitive pressures as they don't need to run for reelection this cycle so they can afford to stay in longer and hope to make the 4th debate.
Hickenlooper & Inslee x'd out and guessing  Bennet / Delaney & Ryan go relatively soon.

Happened: Hickenlooper, Inslee Somewhat likely: Bennet, Bullock, de Blasio, Delaney, Ryan 
Possible: Gabbard, Gillibrand, Williamson 
Very unlikely: Booker, Buttigieg, Castro, Klobuchar, O'Rourke, Yang, Biden, Harris, Sanders, Warren

https://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2019/08/18/andrew_yang_names_23_out_of_24_democratic_candidates_in_one_minute.html Reportedly only 10 of the remaining 22 candidates have qualified for the September debate.
Inslee out today. Hickenlooper out previously. 3 weeks left.

Inslee has dropped out. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/21/us/politics/jay-inslee-2020-campaign.html Edit:
His explanation in email to donors speaks to the debate qualification challenge: “ On Monday, our campaign hit one of two critical DNC thresholds to qualify for the next debate -- 130,000 grassroots donors. Reaching that challenging milestone proves the strong support that defeating climate change has amongst the grassroots of our party. However, at the same time we reached this threshold, it became clear that we would not meet the DNC's polling threshold, thus we would not have been invited to the fall debates. As a result, I don't believe we can compete for the attention and exposure needed to have a reasonable shot at the nomination.”

Inslee and Hickenlooper are out.
Who is next Gillebrand and DeBlasio?

Seems very likely that by the deadline to meet the requirements of donors and polls that more than five will be unable to participate in the next debate. Without being in the debate, they will realize they are not a realistic choice for the Democratic nominee
Similar to 2016 GOP debates, there are specifically 3-4 candidates who have failed to increase poll numbers and/or are seeing declining  rates of fundraising.
not all will qualify for September debates but I do not think they will give up fundraising and running before November
Delaney commits to stay in the race [1].  Forecast unchanged. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/08/15/john-delaney-certainly-plans-to-stay-in-2020-race-if-he-misses-fall-debates.html

s very strong but certainly one or two already shown political frailties and are unlikely toreceive enough support

Here I am testing how sensitive my forecast is to assumptions about individual candidate drop out chances. Suggested names for drop outs before October debate by 538 [1]: 1 Tim Ryan
2 Beto O’Rourke
3 Jay Inslee
4 Steve Bullock
5 Kirsten Gillibrand
6 Bill de Blasio
7 Michael Bennet
-John Hickenlooper (already dropped out)
-Seth Moulton (wasn't in the 2nd debate so doesn't count) Let's assume all of the 7 have a 30% chance of dropping out (individually) before 12 Sept. A stochastic simulation shows there is a 75% chance that more than 1 more candidate will drop out (i.e. buckets 3 and 4). That's higher than I thought. Realistically O'Rourke seems unlikely to drop out given he's gone on the offense against Trump on gun reform and been making a big public push there. Similarly, I may be biased but I think Inslee is extremely unlikely to drop out that early as his prime motivation is to drive his climate policy ideas into the Overton window. Let's say they are both 0. Now probability of 3rd of 4th bucket is 47%. That's actually quite close to my current forecast, which makes me a bit more comfortable with it. Reducing 2nd bucket by 3% points. [1] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/our-first-2020-drop-out-draft/
Rollin' deep with the consensus here. The numbers seem to make the most sense.
Moving 0 to 0% upon news of Hickenlooper dropout. Evenly distributing 10pp between 1-2 and 3-4. Crowd: 3%, 43%, 37%, 17%

I’ve committed the crime of substitution and answered the question “how many won’t qualify for the debate?” but that isn’t the question (it’s a proxy and it’s easier to answer, but still isn’t the original question). It’s possible to not qualify for next debate and also not yet drop out. Revising down based on this.

Hickenlooper dropped out on 8/15, making the Zero answer invalid. As the DNC is raising the qualifying standards for the next debate to 2% in qualifying polls and donations from at least 130,000 individuals, we can expect some winnowing. 9 candidates have qualified for the next debates so far. I think several long-shot candidates will remain in the race hoping that as others drop out, orphaned supporters will coalesce behind them. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/14/us/politics/next-democratic-debate-candidates.html
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/us/2020_democratic_presidential_nomination-6730.html

Of the 20 candidates who participated in the first debates, nine have already qualified for the second debates and one has dropped out (Hickenlooper) with two weeks until the DNC deadline (Aug 28). This 538 article [1]  includes a helpful table of which candidates have met each of the requirements (donors and polls.  Same article indicates another 3-4 are on cusp of qualifying, with the NYT recently profiling four [2].    Even if some candidates don't qualify for the September debates, the DNC has left the door open for them to qualify for the October debates [3].  So, some candidates who don't qualify will still likely continue their campaigns.  As indicated in the helpful historical analysis from @Emil [4] (thank you!) , most candidates stick it out until the first primaries.  Thanks also to @Anneinak for her comments [5] . Conclusions:  7-11 candidates not qualifying, maybe half call it quits (3-6), with one already out.  Bias towards candidates sticking it out longer.  Crowd: 1-2: 44%, 3-4: 33%, 5+: 18%, 0: 5% [1] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/who-will-make-the-third-democratic-debate-and-who-could-miss-it/
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/14/us/politics/next-democratic-debate-candidates.html
[3] https://www.politico.com/story/2019/08/06/dnc-2020-democratic-debate-1448871
[4] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/890692
[5] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/890916

Hicken Looper is being pitched a run for Senate as a change in direction. Others are beginning to hear "Suggestions"about alternative races and preserving future viability. Except De Blasio. He knows everything.
There is no clear frontrunner so everyone thinks they have a chance.

Decreasing 0 on news of Hickenlooper mulling Senate bid. Also decreasing 5+ on discussion here outlining that candidates are much more likely to drop out in fall: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/our-first-2020-drop-out-draft/ Crowd: 8%, 43%, 34%, 15%

Shifting slightly in favor of a higher number. Here's an interesting discussion:

Nine candidates have qualified for the third presidential primary debate and five more candidates are on the cusp with at least one qualifying poll. Julián Castro, Tulsi Gabbard, and Tom Steyer have each met the fundraising threshold. Castro and Steyer are missing one poll and Gabbard three. Kirsten Gillibrand and John Hickenlooper both have one qualifying poll and have not crossed the fundraising threshold.

Likely: Hickenlooper 
Somewhat likely: Bennet, Bullock, de Blasio, Delaney, Ryan 
Possible: Inslee, Gabbard, Gillibrand, Williamson 
Very unlikely: Booker, Buttigieg, Castro, Klobuchar, O'Rourke, Yang, Biden, Harris, Sanders, Warren

DNC just loosened the qualifications for the 4th Democratic presidential debate (to be held in October) [1].  The starting date for the 2% polling number is June 28, the same starting date as the 3rd debate qualification.  This modification essentially means all those qualified for the 3rd debate will qualify for the 4th debate, AND gives more time for those that did not qualify for the 3rd debate. Despite the wish of some voters for a smaller field, DNC decided to put in rules to expand the field (from the 3rd to the 4th debate).  This change provides more hope for the lesser candidates for exposure and news coverage in October.  Instead of dropping out, they might stay on for another chance (in October).   I am reducing the chance for Five or more. [1]  https://www.politico.com/story/2019/08/06/dnc-2020-democratic-debate-1448871

With that next debate being the 3rd out of 4 I see those candidates who have spent a lot of time and money but have yet to see any promising results to start to pull out of the race. To pull out in August would give that candidate plenty of time to regroup and focus on more accomplish-able goals and to boost their approval rating in their respected areas. I see more dropping out of the race after the 3rd debate but August will hold plenty of weight when it comes to who is the front runner for the Democratic party.

Eight candidates have qualified for the September debate so far.  Seven ― former Vice President Joe Biden, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg, former Rep. Beto O’Rourke (D-Texas) and Sen. Cory Booker (D-N.J.) ― qualified by the end July. Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) announced Friday that her campaign had met the donor requirements. To be on the next debate stage, candidates must have more than 2% support in at least four national polls or polls from early-voting states, such as Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada or South Carolina. The candidates must also raise funds from at least 130,000 individual donors and show that they have 400 unique donors from at least 20 different states. All qualifying donations must be made before August 28 and must be endorsed by DNC-approved donation tools such as ActBlue. 
Democratic candidates are introduced before the second of two Democratic presidential primary debates...
AP Photo/Carlos Osorio
Democratic candidates are introduced before the second of two Democratic presidential primary debates hosted by CNN this week. Along with the eight Democrats already set to appear, two candidates are close to qualifying. Former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Julián Castro and entrepreneur Andrew Yang have met the donor requirement, but still need to meet polling numbers.

It seems that it will be failure to meet the DNC standards which will eliminate candidates.   Both articles said to watch for post-debate spikes in fund-raising or polling. The DNC deadline is Aug 28th; this question asks "as of Sept 12th", 2 weeks later. Since I think 8-10 won't make the cut, more than half of them will have to decide to withdraw/suspend for "five or more". . . hm. . .  @Emil

The eight that have qualified have no reason to quit. Julian Castro and Andrew Yang will likely make the debate, as well as Tulsi Gabbard (and if she doesn't, she could try a third party bid). Inslee and Bullock have incentives to stay in (Inslee needs to keep pushing on climate to maybe become energy secretary, Bullock appealed to some voters in the second debate and is well received in Iowa) and not many to leave. Hickenlooper could run for senate, and doesn't have much left for him in the race. Tim Ryan will probably want to run for his house seat again. Delaney,  Gillibrand, Williamson, De Blasio, and Bennet all lack clear incentives to leave the race this early, but also could leave because of exhaustion and the perceived futility of their run (depending on the candidate).
Pretty soon the financing will run out, as will the free media coverage

Not qualifying for debate #3 doesn't mean that someone has ceased to be a candidate, but it's close enough. Aside from money drying up, pressure to just go away, etc., the possibility exists that someone who hangs on too long will become, or be portrayed as, a laughingstock. For an ambitious politician, that's fatal. Remember Harold Stassen. Gillibrand, Hickenlooper, Delaney, Di Blasio, and Gabbard are the most serious candidates who will probably quit. If they want to continue to play the presidential game in the future, they can't afford to look stupid, so I would imagine most, if not all, of them will have to bow out quite soon. Castro may manage to pull it off for debate 3, but if he doesn't, he'll probably wind up withdrawing before he prompts any whispers that he's just being pathetic. Inslee, Bullock, Ryan and Bennet count as far as this question goes, and there's a pretty good chance that all of them will drop out. So anyway, we're looking at at least five. Yang, Steyer and Williamson are essentially vanity candidates, so they might stick around because they don't have much to lose. Yang and Steyer (but probably not Williamson) may entertain fantasies of being the Democratic Trump. I don't think any of the three will drop out before the next debate.

In my analysis on the previous question I looked at base rates for previous primary races since 1980 [1], which showed that: 32% of candidates cease to be candidates by the February caucuses, with a standard deviation of 11 percentage points. To make this forecast, I make some additional assumptions: Argument/Method #1 (Base Rates) * Let's assume the race started in July (more precisely what I mean is that dropping out begins to be a possibility in July). That's 7 months to the caucuses. 
* In total there were 21 candidates. 1 has already dropped out (Salwell)
* For now, I assume linear trend in candidate-drop-out per month This suggests there will be 7 drop outs by the first caucuses (assuming they are in Feb) (68% confidence interval of 5-9 and 95% of 2-11), and using the linear assumption, there would be 1 per month (95% interval is 0-2 roughly speaking). This is consistent with what we observed in July. Argument/Method #2 (another historical perspective) The previous method is agnostic to the schedule of the actual race. It is important to acknowledge that this race is occurring sooner than in the past ( the debates are taking place sooner, perhaps owing to the large candidate field).

In the 2016 GOP primary (the closest historical analog in terms of the large number of candidates), the drop-outs were: 2 in September, 1 in November, and 2 in December. [2] Two candidates had dropped out by the beginning of the 3rd debate [4]. This is consistent with my numbers above. Argument/Method #3 (Inside View) This candidate field larger than any in my historical data set and we have to acknowledge that a larger field will see more drop outs (there is only so much donor money to go around and support to garner).  Most haven't yet qualified for the third debate. [3] On the other hand, why would a candidate drop out this early? For candidates that are clearly behind, is participation in the debate absolutely necessary to fulfill the goals they had when joining the race:
* raising ones profile for e.g. a Senate run - My impression there is plenty of time to register for Senate races (late in the fall if I remember correctly). So there doesn't seem to be a rush from that standpoint. 
* raising the prominence of a given issue (e.g. Inslee with climate change) - not qualifying for a debate significantly reduces ones chances of doing this so this may provide impetus for candidates to drop out Therefore I am shifting the distribution up. Still "five or more" would be very surprising given the historical record. Forecasters whom I respect such as @Anneinak and @MaRott are allocating a high chance for five or more to drop out. I wonder if that is purely based on qualification for the 3rd debate? [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/874330
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/874536
[3] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/01/us/politics/next-democratic-debate.html
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Republican_Party_presidential_debates_and_forums#August_6,_2015_–_Cleveland,_Ohio

Again I examined the recent crowded Republican primary and debates in 2015-2016 looking for guidance on how many Democratic candidates will drop out before the third debate on September 12-13. Only 1 Republican candidate dropped out after the first debate [1].  One additional candidate (total of 2) dropped out after the second debate.  By the fifth debate, only a total of 3 candidates dropped out.  By the Iowa primary, there were still 12 candidates (a total of 5 dropped out by that time).  The drop-out rate was not high after each debate.   However, the Republican debates were divided into two tiers using poll data.  While the second-tier candidates were not invited to the first-tier debates, they still have debate and coverage exposure, albeit much less, in the second-tier debates.   The situation is different in this Democratic primary and debates.  For the third Democratic debate, the number of participants will be cut down significantly.  To be invited, a candidate has to have more than 130,000 donors and have at least 2% polling in 4 qualified polls.  As of today, there are 8 candidates that have past these thresholds [2].   Two candidates have the number of donors but need another poll to qualify.  Three more candidates have some potential, albeit small, to get there.  The rest (11) candidates are not even close to qualifying.  It seems clear that at least half of the candidates will not qualify to the debates, and therefore it will be only one debate with about 10 people – there is no second tier debate like the 2016 Republican debates.  Without exposure from debates, there is no way that these candidates can survive.  Will they drop out before this third debate?  They may not for a while.  However, the answer to the forecast is easier because the choices are 0, 1-2, 3-4 and 5 or more.  It would be much harder if there are more choices at numbers greater than 5.  But it is what it is.  I am going all the way in forecasting 100% for five or more candidates to drop out.  [1]  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Republican_Party_presidential_debates_and_forums
[2]  https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/01/us/politics/next-democratic-debate.html

I suspect at least Hickenlooper or Ryan, if not both, will drop out due to near certainty of missing the next debate and lack of traction. I feel there’s a fair likelihood that at least one or two others who miss the next debate (likely 8-10 of those in the second debate) will also drop out, possibly just before the next debate once the time to qualify passed, while the rest stubbornly stay in or give the news that they’re dropping out during or immediately after the third debates to minimize the media attention on their dropout. I think there’s an equal chance of many more dropping out or none at all. Will do more analysis later.
